metadata.title: AGC Office 365 GovCloud - FedRAMP System Security Plan (SSP)

roles.title: FedRAMP Program Management Office
roles.description: The FedRAMP PMO resides within GSA and supports agencies and cloud service providers through the FedRAMP authorization process and maintains a secure repository of FedRAMP authorizations to enable reuse of security packages.

roles.title: FedRAMP Program Management Office
roles.description: Members of the JAB include the chief information officers (CIOs) from the Department of Defense, Department of Homeland Security, and General Services Administration. The JAB serves as the primary governance and decision-making body for FedRAMP.

roles.title: Allen Baniya
roles.description: The organization that prepared this SSP. If developed in-house, this is the CSP itself.

roles.title: Prepared For Animo Government Consulting
roles.description: The organization for which this SSP was prepared. Typically the CSP.

roles.title: System Security Plan Approval
roles.description: The individual or individuals accountable for the accuracy of this SSP.

roles.title: Information System Owner
roles.description: The individual within the CSP who is ultimately accountable for everything related to this system.

roles.title: Authorizing Official
roles.description: The individual or individuals who must grant this system an authorization to operate.

roles.title: Authorizing Official's Point of Contact
roles.description: The individual representing the authorizing official.

roles.title: Information System Management Point of Contact (POC)
roles.description: The highest level manager who responsible for system operation on behalf of the System Owner.

roles.title: Chief Executive Officer
roles.description: Responsible for overall company strategy and direction.

roles.title: Chief Technology Officer
roles.description: Responsible for technological decisions and strategy.

roles.title: Chief Operating Officer / Chief Growth Officer
roles.description: Responsible for operations and growth strategies.

roles.title: Information System Technical Point of Contact
roles.description: The individual or individuals leading the technical operation of the system.

roles.title: General Point of Contact (POC)
roles.description: A general point of contact for the system, designated by the system owner.

roles.title: System Information System Security Officer (or Equivalent)
roles.description: The individual accountable for the security posture of the system on behalf of the system owner.

roles.title: Privacy Official's Point of Contact
roles.description: The individual responsible for the privacy threshold analysis and if necessary the privacy impact assessment.

roles.title: Owner of an inventory item within the system.
Administrative responsibility an inventory item within the system.
ICA POC (Local)
roles.description: The point of contact for an interconnection on behalf of this system.
roles.remarks: Remove this role if there are no ICAs.

roles.title: ICA POC (Remote)
roles.description: The point of contact for an interconnection on behalf of this external system to which this system connects.
roles.remarks: Remove this role if there are no ICAs.

roles.title: ICA Signatory (Local)
roles.description: Responsible for signing an interconnection security agreement on behalf of this system.
roles.remarks: Remove this role if there are no ICAs.

roles.title: ICA Signatory (Remote)
roles.description: Responsible for signing an interconnection security agreement on behalf of the external system to which this system connects.
roles.remarks: Remove this role if there are no ICAs.

roles.title: Consultant
roles.description: Any consultants involved with developing or maintaining this content.

roles.title: Customer
roles.description: Represents any customers of this system as may be necessary for assigning customer responsibility.

roles.title: [SAMPLE]Unix Administrator
roles.description: This is a sample role.

roles.title: [SAMPLE]Client Administrator
roles.description: This is a sample role.

locations.title: CSP HQ
locations.remarks: There must be one location identifying the CSP's primary business address, such as the CSP's HQ, or the address of the system owner's primary business location.

locations.title: Primary Data Center
locations.remarks:
There must be one location for each data center.

There must be at least two data center locations.

For a data center, briefly summarize the components at this location.

All data centers must have a \"type\" property with a value of \"data-center\".

The type property must also have a class of \"primary\" or \"alternate\".

locations.title: Secondary Data Center
locations.remarks:
There must be one location for each data center.

There must be at least two data center locations.

For a data center, briefly summarize the components at this location.

All data centers must have a \"type\" property with a value of \"data-center\".

The type property must also have a class of \"primary\" or \"alternate\".

parties.name: AGC Office 365 GovCloud
parties.remarks:
Replace sample CSP information.

CSP information must be present and associated with the \"cloud-service-provider\" role via `responsible-party`.

parties.name: Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program: Program Management Office
parties.remarks:
This party entry must be present in a FedRAMP SSP.

The uuid may be different; however, the uuid must be associated with the \"fedramp-pmo\" role in the responsible-party assemblies.

parties.name: Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program: Joint Authorization Board
parties.remarks:
This party entry must be present in a FedRAMP SSP.

The uuid may be different; however, the uuid must be associated with the \"fedramp-jab\" role in the responsible-party assemblies.

parties.name: External Organization
parties.remarks: Generic placeholder for any external organization.

parties.name: Department of Veteran Affairs (Agency)
parties.remarks: Generic placeholder for an authorizing agency.

parties.name: Microsoft Office 365 GCC High -  IaaS Provider

props.name: job-title
props.value: Chief Operating Officer / Chief Growth Officer

metadata.remarks:
This OSCAL-based FedRAMP SSP Template can be used for the FedRAMP Low, Moderate, and High baselines.

Guidance for OSCAL-based FedRAMP Tailored Low Impact - Software as a Service (LI-SaaS) content has not yet been developed.

import-profile.remarks:
This example points to the FedRAMP Rev 5 Moderate baseline that is part of the official FedRAMP 1.0.4 release.

Must adjust accordingly for applicable baseline and revision.

system-characteristics.description:
AGC Office 365 GovCloud is delivered as [a/an] SaaS offering using a multi-tenant hybrid-cloud computing environment. It is available to [Insert scope of customers in accordance with instructions above (for example, the public, federal, state, local, and tribal governments, as well as research institutions, federal contractors, government contractors etc.)].

NOTE: Additional description, including the purpose and functions of this system may be added here. This includes any narrative text usually included in section 9.1 of the SSP.

AGC Office 365 GovCloud is a comprehensive cloud-based solution leveraging Microsoft Office 365 Enterprise High FedRAMP, integrated with various high-security cloud services to provide a robust and secure environment for government agencies.

props.name: cloud-service-model
props.remarks: Remarks are required if service model is \"other\". Optional otherwise.

props.name: cloud-deployment-model
props.remarks: Remarks are required if deployment model is hybrid-cloud.

integrity-impact.adjustment-justification: Required if the base and selected values do not match.

availability-impact.adjustment-justification: Required if the base and selected values do not match.

status.remarks:
Remarks are optional if status/state is \"operational\".

Remarks are required otherwise.

authorization-boundary.description: A holistic, top-level explanation of the FedRAMP authorization boundary.The authorization boundary includes all components of the AGC Office 365 GovCloud, including Microsoft Office 365 Enterprise High FedRAMP, Azure AAD, Atlassian Cloud, Salesforce Cloud, and Azure High Cloud virtual machines and their associated services.

network-architecture.description: A holistic, top-level explanation of the network architecture. The authorization boundary includes all components of the AGC Office 365 GovCloud, including Microsoft Office 365 Enterprise High FedRAMP, Azure AAD, Atlassian Cloud, Salesforce Cloud, and Azure High Cloud virtual machines and their associated services.

data-flow.description: A holistic, top-level explanation of the system's data flows.

leveraged-authorizations.title: GovCloud
leveraged-authorizations.remarks:
Use one leveraged-authorization assembly for each underlying system. In the legacy world, these may be general support systems.

The link fields are optional, but preferred when known. Often, a leveraging system's SSP author will not have access to the leveraged system's SSP, but should have access to the leveraged system's CRM.

For data-at-rest modules, describe type of encryption implemented (e.g., full disk, file, record-level, etc.)

Lastly, provide any supporting notes on FIPS status (e.g. historical) or lack of FIPS compliance (e.g., Module in Process).

For example, any supporting notes on FIPS status (e.g. historical) or lack of FIPS compliance (e.g., Module in Process).

control-implementation.description:
Appendix A - FedRAMP SSP Rev5 Template

This description field is required by OSCAL.

FedRAMP does not require any specific information here.

by-components.description: AGC Office 365 GovCloud has developed, documented, and disseminated to appropriate personnel an access control policy that addresses purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, management commitment, coordination among organizational entities, and compliance. The access control policy is reviewed and updated annually by the Information Security team and approved by the CTO.

values: CTO, Information Security Team, System Administrators

by-components.description: AGC Office 365 GovCloud uses Azure Active Directory (AAD) for account management. The system identifies and selects types of accounts to support organizational missions/business functions. Account management processes are automated where possible, and manual processes are documented and consistently followed.

AGC Office 365 GovCloud, as the core system, identifies and selects the following types of information system accounts to support organizational missions/business functions: privileged, non-privileged, and shared. The system leverages Azure Active Directory (AAD) for centralized account management and integrates with Microsoft Office 365 Enterprise services to provide a comprehensive account management solution.

provided.description: AGC Office 365 GovCloud provides the capability to create, enable, modify, disable, and remove accounts through Azure Active Directory. It supports role-based access control, multi-factor authentication, and advanced auditing features to enhance account security and management.

responsibilities.description: AGC, as the cloud service provider, is responsible for maintaining the core account management infrastructure, ensuring proper integration with Azure Active Directory, and providing documentation and guidance on best practices for account management.

by-components.description: Azure Active Directory (AAD) is configured within AGC Office 365 GovCloud to support the creation, enabling, modification, disabling, and removal of various account types. AAD provides a robust set of features for managing user identities, including group-based access management, privileged identity management, and conditional access policies.

provided.description: Azure AD offers customers the ability to define and manage different account types, implement custom access policies, and utilize advanced security features such as risk-based conditional access and privileged identity management.

responsibilities.description: Customers are responsible for configuring Azure AD according to their organizational policies, managing their user accounts, implementing appropriate access controls, and monitoring account activities within their Azure AD environment.

by-components.remarks: Azure Active Directory serves as the primary component for implementing account management controls in AGC Office 365 GovCloud, providing a centralized identity and access management solution that integrates with various Microsoft 365 services.

by-components.description: AGC Office 365 GovCloud inherits certain account management capabilities from the underlying Microsoft Office 365 Enterprise High FedRAMP authorization, which provides a secure foundation for implementing robust account management practices.

inherited.description: The FedRAMP High authorized Microsoft Office 365 platform provides underlying account management capabilities, including secure authentication mechanisms, account lifecycle management, and integration with Azure Active Directory for centralized identity management.

satisfied.description: AGC Office 365 GovCloud has implemented additional account management controls on top of the inherited capabilities to meet specific FedRAMP High requirements and customer needs. This includes enhanced auditing of account activities, implementation of multi-factor authentication for all privileged accounts, and regular review and recertification of user access rights.

by-components.description: AGC has developed and documented a comprehensive security awareness and training policy. This policy establishes a framework to ensure that all personnel understand their security responsibilities and comply with AGC's information security policies. The policy covers all aspects of AGC's information security program and affects all employees, contractors, and third-party entities involved in the management, execution, or oversight of information security activities.

The Awareness & Training Policy defines roles and responsibilities for key personnel, including the Chief Executive Officer, Chief Information Security Officer, Program Manager, all employees and contractors, and Human Resources. It outlines the requirements for security awareness training (AT-2), role-based security training (AT-3), maintenance of security training records (AT-4), and establishing contacts with security groups and associations (AT-5).

AGC has implemented procedures to ensure consistent implementation of the security awareness and training policy. These procedures include processes for delivering basic security awareness training to all personnel, providing specialized training for those with specific security roles, maintaining training records, and staying informed about current security threats and best practices through contacts with security groups and associations.

AGC disseminates the security awareness and training policy to all relevant personnel within the organization. This includes employees, contractors, and third-party entities involved in information security activities. The policy is made available through the company's internal policy repository and is communicated during onboarding and regular security awareness sessions.

AGC reviews and updates the security awareness and training policy and procedures annually. This review process ensures that the policy remains current, relevant, and aligned with the organization's evolving security needs and compliance requirements. The Chief Information Security Officer is responsible for overseeing this review process and implementing any necessary updates or changes.

AGC has developed, documented, and disseminated to appropriate personnel a comprehensive audit and accountability policy. This policy establishes a framework for the auditing and accountability of AGC's information systems to ensure the security, integrity, and availability of data and to support compliance with applicable laws and regulations.

values: Chief Information Security Officer, Program Manager, System Administrators

by-components.description: AGC identifies and documents the specific events that require auditing. The organization audits events necessary to support after-the-fact investigations of security incidents and to meet regulatory requirements.

AGC ensures that audit records include sufficient information to establish what events occurred, the sources of the events, and the outcomes of the events. This includes date and time of the event, source of the event, user or process associated with the event, description of the event, and success or failure of the event.
AGC allocates sufficient audit record storage capacity to retain audit records for a period consistent with the organization's compliance requirements.
AGC implements measures to respond to audit processing failures, including alerting appropriate personnel and shutting down information system components if necessary.
AGC regularly reviews, analyzes, and reports on audit records to identify anomalous activity and potential security incidents. This process includes automated mechanisms where feasible.
AGC implements audit reduction and report generation capabilities to support the analysis and reporting of audit records. This includes filtering and summarizing audit data.
AGC's information systems use internal system clocks to generate time stamps for audit records. Time stamps are synchronized across the organization's information systems.
AGC protects audit information and audit tools from unauthorized access, modification, and deletion. This includes implementing access controls and encryption.
AGC implements measures to ensure the non-repudiation of audit records, ensuring that actions can be attributed to specific users or processes without denial.

AGC retains audit records for a period consistent with the organization's compliance requirements, typically at least one year, to support security incident investigations and regulatory requirements.
AGC's information systems generate audit records for defined events and provide the capability to generate and forward audit records to a centralized audit review and analysis system.

AGC has developed, documented, and disseminated to appropriate personnel a comprehensive security assessment and authorization policy and procedures. This policy establishes the framework for conducting security assessments, managing system authorizations, and ensuring continuous monitoring of security controls.

values: Chief Information Security Officer, Information System Security Officer, System Administrators

by-components.description: AGC's security assessment and authorization policy addresses purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, management commitment, coordination among organizational entities, and compliance with relevant laws, regulations, and standards.

The security assessment and authorization policy is documented and maintained as part of AGC's overall information security policy framework. It provides guidance on conducting security assessments, managing the authorization process, and implementing continuous monitoring practices.

AGC has established procedures to facilitate the implementation of the security assessment and authorization policy and associated controls. These procedures detail the steps for conducting assessments, granting authorizations, and performing continuous monitoring activities.

AGC reviews and updates the security assessment and authorization policy annually to ensure it remains relevant and aligned with organizational goals, industry best practices, and regulatory requirements.

AGC reviews and updates the security assessment and authorization procedures annually to ensure they effectively support the implementation of the policy and address any changes in the operational environment or regulatory landscape.

AGC conducts security assessments on the information system and its environment of operation to determine the extent to which security controls are implemented correctly, operating as intended, and producing the desired outcome with respect to meeting established security requirements.
AGC documents and monitors interconnections between the information system and other systems. Interconnection Security Agreements are established for all system interconnections.

AGC develops and maintains a plan of action and milestones (POA&M) that documents the planned remedial actions to correct weaknesses or deficiencies noted during the assessment of the security controls and to reduce or eliminate known vulnerabilities in the system.

AGC assigns a senior-level executive or manager as the authorizing official for the information system. The authorizing official authorizes the information system for operation prior to commencing operations.

AGC develops and implements a continuous monitoring strategy and program that includes ongoing security control assessments, security impact analyses of changes to the system and environment of operation, and security status reporting to appropriate organizational officials.

AGC has developed, documented, and disseminated a comprehensive configuration management policy that addresses purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, management commitment, coordination among organizational entities, and compliance. The policy is reviewed and updated annually or as needed to reflect changes in organizational requirements and the threat environment.

values: Chief Information Security Officer, IT Department, Configuration Management team

by-components.description: AGC's IT department establishes and documents baseline configurations for all organizational information systems, including hardware inventory, software inventory, network topology and configurations, security settings, and patch levels. Baseline configurations are stored in a centralized Configuration Management Database (CMDB) and version-controlled. The Configuration Management team reviews and updates baseline configurations annually, when new systems are introduced, following major system upgrades, and in response to significant security incidents.

AGC manages all changes to the configuration of information systems through a formal change management process, which includes a Change Request Form, risk assessment and security impact analysis, approval by the Change Advisory Board (CAB), documentation of change details, implementation planning, and post-implementation review. AGC implements automated mechanisms to track changes to system configurations, notify appropriate personnel of proposed changes, and prohibit changes without proper approvals.

AGC's Security team conducts security impact analyses for all proposed changes to assess potential effects on system security. This analysis includes vulnerability assessment, compliance impact evaluation, data protection implications, and access control modifications. Security impact analyses are documented and stored in the change management system, linked to the corresponding change request. Changes with high security impact require additional approval from the Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) or designee.

AGC implements role-based access control (RBAC) to restrict system and configuration change capabilities to authorized personnel only. Multi-factor authentication (MFA) is required for all administrative access to production systems. All privileged actions are logged and monitored using a Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) system.

AGC's IT department establishes and documents secure configuration settings for all information systems based on various sources such as Center for Internet Security (CIS) benchmarks, DISA STIGs, and vendor-recommended security practices. Configuration settings are managed using automated configuration management tools to ensure consistency across the environment while performing continuous monitoring to detect and alert on unauthorized changes to configuration settings. Deviations or exceptions to approved configuration settings must be documented, risk-assessed, and approved by the CISO.

AGC configures information systems to provide only essential capabilities by disabling or removing unnecessary services, ports, and protocols, implementing application whitelisting, and enforcing the principle of least privilege for user and service accounts. AGC maintains an inventory of approved services, ports, and protocols, which is reviewed and updated semi-annually. The IT team conducts quarterly port scans and service enumeration to identify and disable unnecessary functions. Any request to enable additional functionality must be justified, risk-assessed, and approved through the change management process.

AGC has developed, implemented, and maintains a comprehensive Contingency Planning Policy that outlines the processes and procedures for preparing for, responding to, and recovering from unexpected disruptions to organizational operations. This policy aligns with NIST SP 800-53 Revision 5 controls, FedRAMP moderate baseline requirements, and FEMA standards.

values: Chief Information Security Officer, Program Manager, All Employees and Contractors

by-components.description: AGC has developed, implemented, and maintains a comprehensive contingency plan that addresses the recovery of critical business functions, systems, and data within predefined recovery time objectives (RTOs) and recovery point objectives (RPOs). The plan is based on regular risk assessments and business impact analyses to identify critical systems and processes.

AGC conducts regular training and awareness programs on contingency planning procedures for all relevant personnel. These programs ensure that staff are familiar with their roles and responsibilities during a contingency event.

AGC performs contingency plan drills and exercises at least annually to test the plan and identify areas for improvement. These tests include multiple recovery strategies, including backup and restoration procedures, alternate processing sites, and redundant systems.

AGC has established clear communication protocols for internal and external stakeholders during contingency operations. This includes coordination with federal, state, and local emergency management agencies.

AGC has established and maintains alternate processing sites as part of its recovery strategies. These sites are tested regularly to ensure their effectiveness in supporting critical business functions during contingency operations.

AGC has implemented redundant telecommunications services to ensure continued communications during contingency operations. These services are tested regularly as part of the overall contingency planning exercises.

AGC conducts regular backups of critical system data, software, and documentation. These backups are stored at secure off-site locations and are tested periodically to ensure their integrity and availability for restoration when needed.

AGC implements a continuous improvement process for its contingency planning. This includes documenting lessons learned from actual incidents and testing exercises, and using them to improve the contingency plan. The plan is reviewed and updated at least annually or following significant changes to the organizational environment.

AGC has developed, disseminated, and annually reviews a formal, documented identification and authentication policy and procedures to ensure consistent implementation across the organization. The policy and procedures are approved by the Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) and made available to all organizational users.

values: Chief Information Security Officer, Program Manager, All Employees and Contractors

by-components.description: AGC ensures that all organizational users are uniquely identified and authenticated before accessing the information systems. Multi-factor authentication (MFA) is implemented for all user access, providing an additional layer of security.

AGC implements unique identification and authentication for all devices accessing the information systems. This includes the use of strong device certificates issued by a trusted Certificate Authority (CA).

AGC manages user identifiers by ensuring they are unique, assigned promptly, and deactivated when no longer needed. Each account follows a standardized naming convention of [first name][last name]@animogovcon.com.

AGC manages authenticators securely, including the use of strong passwords, regular password changes, and protected password storage. Account passwords must be a minimum of 12 characters in length and meet complexity requirements defined by NIST SP 800-63B. Multi-factor authentication is mandatory for all high-impact information systems, as mandated by FedRAMP High Baseline controls.

AGC provides clear and timely feedback to users during the authentication process, indicating successful or unsuccessful authentication attempts. This feedback is provided in a manner that does not compromise sensitive information.

AGC ensures that non-organizational users (e.g., partners, contractors) accessing the information systems are uniquely identified and authenticated. Access is restricted to necessary resources only, using role-based access control (RBAC). Prior to account provision, non-organizational user accounts are sponsored by an organizational user and approved by the CISO.

AGC authenticates non-organizational users using federated identity management (FIM) or single sign-on (SSO) solutions. Non-organizational user authentication includes role-based access control (RBAC).

AGC implements comprehensive account management procedures including account provisioning within 1 business day, account review every 60 days, account disablement or termination within 1 business day of request, and account expiration after 90 days of inactivity. All accounts adhere to a standardized naming convention and password management policies in line with NIST SP 800-63B and FedRAMP High Baseline controls.

AGC has established and maintains a comprehensive Incident Response Policy and Incident Response Plan (IRP) that outlines the processes and procedures for effectively managing and responding to security incidents. The policy and plan align with NIST SP 800-53 Revision 5 controls, FedRAMP moderate baseline requirements, and FEMA standards.

values: Chief Information Security Officer, Incident Response Manager, Program Manager

by-components.description: AGC provides comprehensive incident response training to all relevant personnel at least annually. This training covers incident response policies and procedures, individual roles and responsibilities, incident identification and reporting processes, use of incident response tools and technologies, communication protocols during an incident, and legal and regulatory compliance requirements. Specialized, role-based training is provided to members of the Incident Response Team, covering advanced incident handling techniques, forensic analysis, and crisis management.

AGC conducts regular testing of the incident response capability through various methods including quarterly tabletop exercises, annual full-scale simulations of major incidents, and other drills. These tests are documented, and results are used to improve the incident response processes. The incident response plan is reviewed and updated at least annually or after significant changes in the IT environment.

AGC follows a structured incident handling process based on the NIST SP 800-61 Computer Security Incident Handling Guide, which consists of four main phases: Preparation, Detection & Analysis, Containment, Eradication & Recovery, and Post-Incident Activity. All incidents are reported immediately to the designated incident response team. The incident response team classifies, prioritizes, and handles incidents according to their severity and impact on the organization. Procedures are established for coordinating and communicating with internal and external parties, including law enforcement, during incident response activities.

AGC implements continuous monitoring for incidents to ensure timely detection. Detailed records of incidents, including actions taken and lessons learned, are maintained and reviewed periodically. The incident response process includes specific steps for tracking and documenting incidents throughout their lifecycle, from initial detection through post-incident analysis.

AGC has established clear reporting procedures for internal and external stakeholders documented within the AGC Incident Response Plan. Incidents affecting critical systems are reported to relevant federal authorities as required by law. The communication plan includes guidelines for internal communication using secure, pre-established channels, and external communication coordinated with legal and PR teams. Templates are prepared for different scenarios such as customer notifications and press releases.

AGC provides an incident response support resource that offers advice and assistance for handling and reporting security incidents. This support is integrated into the incident handling process and is available to all members of the Incident Response Team and other relevant personnel. The support includes access to technical expertise, forensic analysis capabilities, and guidance on legal and regulatory compliance during incident response activities.

AGC has developed and implemented a comprehensive Maintenance Policy that ensures all organizational information systems and assets are maintained securely and efficiently to prevent disruptions and facilitate recovery. This policy covers controlled maintenance, maintenance tools, nonlocal maintenance, and maintenance records.

values: Chief Information Security Officer, Program Manager, IT Department

by-components.description: AGC schedules and conducts maintenance activities, including repairs and upgrades, in a manner that minimizes disruptions to operations. Only authorized personnel are permitted to perform maintenance on information systems and assets. All maintenance activities are documented and reviewed periodically to ensure compliance with policies.

AGC approves, manages, and controls all maintenance tools, whether hardware or software, to prevent unauthorized access. Tools that are not required for immediate maintenance are removed from the environment. This approach ensures that only necessary and authorized tools are present during maintenance activities.

AGC authorizes, monitors, and controls all remote maintenance activities to ensure security. Authentication and encryption are utilized for all remote maintenance connections, providing an additional layer of security for these potentially vulnerable access points.

AGC maintains detailed records of all maintenance activities. These records include information about the personnel involved, the tools used, and the results of the maintenance. This comprehensive documentation enables effective tracking, auditing, and review of maintenance activities to ensure compliance and identify any potential issues or trends.

AGC has developed and implemented a comprehensive Media Protection Policy that ensures media containing sensitive information is protected against unauthorized access, use, disclosure, disruption, modification, or destruction. This policy covers media access, sanitization, disposal, transport, and protection training.

values: Chief Information Security Officer, Program Manager, IT Department

by-components.description: AGC restricts access to media containing sensitive information to authorized personnel only. Policies and procedures have been established for labeling, handling, and storing media. AGC implements access controls to prevent unauthorized access to sensitive media, ensuring the confidentiality and integrity of the information stored on these media.

AGC ensures that media no longer required by the organization is sanitized or destroyed in accordance with federal standards to prevent unauthorized disclosure. This process applies to all types of media, including digital and physical formats. AGC maintains detailed records of all media sanitization and disposal activities to ensure compliance and provide an audit trail.

AGC provides comprehensive training to all personnel handling media on proper media protection practices and procedures. This training covers topics such as media classification, secure handling, storage, transport, and disposal methods. The training is conducted regularly to ensure all personnel are aware of the latest media protection requirements and best practices.

AGC has implemented robust procedures for securing media transport outside of controlled areas. This includes the use of encryption for digital media and tamper-evident packaging for physical media. The transport procedures ensure accountability and protection of media during transit, including chain of custody documentation and secure delivery confirmation.

AGC employs secure media sanitization and disposal methods in accordance with federal standards. These methods are designed to prevent the recovery of sensitive information from disposed media. The organization maintains detailed records of all media sanitization and disposal activities, including the date, method used, and personnel involved, to ensure compliance and facilitate audits.

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks: Describe the plan to complete the implementation.

by-components.description: Describe how the control is satisfied within the system.

AGC has developed, documented, and disseminated comprehensive security planning policies and procedures. These policies and procedures are reviewed and updated annually or when significant changes occur in the threat landscape or regulatory requirements. The Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) is responsible for overseeing the development and maintenance of these policies.

values: Chief Information Security Officer, Program Manager, All Employees and Contractors

by-components.description: AGC develops and maintains a comprehensive System Security Plan (SSP) for each information system. Each SSP includes an overview of the system's security requirements, a description of the security controls in place or planned, and any applicable overlays. The SSP is reviewed and updated at least annually or when significant changes are made to the system. The System Owner, in collaboration with the Information System Security Officer (ISSO), is responsible for developing and maintaining the SSP.

AGC has established and maintains Rules of Behavior for all information system users. These rules describe user responsibilities and expected behavior regarding information and system usage. All users must acknowledge and agree to the Rules of Behavior before being granted access to any AGC information system. The Rules of Behavior are reviewed annually and updated as necessary.

AGC develops and maintains an information security architecture that aligns with the enterprise architecture. This architecture is reviewed and updated annually or when significant changes occur in the organization's IT infrastructure. The CISO, in collaboration with the Enterprise Architect, is responsible for developing and maintaining the information security architecture.

AGC implements centralized management of security planning, development, implementation, and operations of information systems. A Security Operations Center (SOC) has been established to oversee and manage security operations across all systems. The SOC reports directly to the CISO and provides regular updates on the organization's security posture.

AGC develops and documents baseline configurations for all information systems. These baselines are based on CIS Benchmarks or DISA STIGs where applicable. Baseline configurations are reviewed and updated annually or when significant changes occur in the system environment. The ISSO, in collaboration with system administrators, is responsible for developing and maintaining baseline configurations.

AGC has established and maintains configuration management policies and procedures. These policies cover configuration change control processes, configuration monitoring, and configuration item identification and tracking. Configuration management policies and procedures are reviewed and updated annually. The Configuration Manager, under the supervision of the CISO, is responsible for developing and maintaining these policies and procedures.

AGC has developed, disseminated, and annually reviews a formal, documented personnel security policy and accompanying procedures to ensure consistent implementation across the organization. This policy establishes authoritative guidance for ensuring all personnel accessing AGC's information systems and data meet stringent security requirements and are adequately vetted to protect the organization's assets and information.

values: Chief Information Security Officer, Human Resources, Program Manager

by-components.description: AGC assigns a risk designation to all positions and establishes screening criteria based on the sensitivity and risk level of the position. Higher risk positions require more stringent screening processes. This ensures that personnel are appropriately vetted based on their access to sensitive information and systems.

All personnel undergo thorough background checks and security screenings before being granted access to AGC's information systems. This screening process is repeated periodically to ensure ongoing compliance. The depth and breadth of the screening process are commensurate with the risk and sensitivity level of the position.

Upon termination of employment, AGC immediately revokes access to information systems, retrieves all organizational assets, and ensures that former employees cannot access any sensitive data. This process includes disabling accounts, collecting physical access devices, and conducting exit interviews to remind departing personnel of their ongoing security obligations.

When personnel are reassigned or transferred within the organization, AGC reviews and confirms access authorizations to ensure they are appropriate for the new position. This includes modifying access rights, re-evaluating security clearances if necessary, and providing any additional training required for the new role.

All personnel sign access agreements before being granted access to organizational information systems, acknowledging their understanding and acceptance of their security responsibilities. These agreements are reviewed and updated annually, and personnel are required to re-sign when there are significant changes to the agreement or the individual's role.

Third-party personnel comply with AGC's personnel security policies and procedures. Contracts with third parties include clauses ensuring compliance with these policies. AGC monitors third-party personnel for compliance and takes appropriate action when violations occur, including termination of contracts if necessary.

AGC employs a formal sanctions process for personnel who fail to comply with established information security policies and procedures. This process includes a range of disciplinary actions, up to and including termination of employment. The sanctions are consistently applied, communicated to all personnel, and reviewed regularly to ensure their effectiveness in deterring policy violations.

AGC has developed, documented, and disseminated a comprehensive system and communications protection policy. This policy is reviewed and updated annually or when significant changes occur in the organizational environment or regulatory landscape. The policy covers all aspects of system and communications protection, including application partitioning, boundary protection, cryptography, and network security.

values: Chief Information Security Officer, Program Manager, IT Security Team

by-components.description: AGC separates user functionality from system management functionality and implements logical separation between user and administrative interfaces. This separation helps prevent unauthorized access to system management functions and protects the integrity of the system.

AGC prevents unauthorized information transfer via shared system resources by implementing process isolation techniques and access controls. This ensures that information from one user or process cannot be inadvertently accessed by another user or process.

AGC implements and maintains boundary protection mechanisms, including next-generation firewalls, intrusion detection/prevention systems, and web application firewalls. Communications are monitored and controlled at external and key internal boundaries, and subnetworks are implemented for publicly accessible system components to enhance security.

AGC employs cryptographic mechanisms to protect the confidentiality and integrity of transmitted information. This includes using TLS 1.2 or higher for web-based communications, IPsec for VPNs, and implementing DNSSEC for DNS integrity verification.
AGC terminates network connections after 30 minutes of inactivity to reduce the risk of unauthorized access to inactive sessions.

AGC employs FIPS-validated cryptographic modules and establishes a robust key management process. This includes implementing secure key generation, storage, distribution, and revocation procedures, with regular key rotation schedules to maintain the security of cryptographic operations.

AGC issues public key certificates under an appropriate certificate policy or obtains them from an approved service provider. An inventory of all certificates is maintained and reviewed quarterly for approaching expiration dates to ensure continuous availability of valid certificates.

AGC implements FIPS-validated cryptographic mechanisms to protect the confidentiality and integrity of information at rest. Access controls are applied and regular integrity checks are conducted on stored data to ensure its protection against unauthorized access or modification.

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks: Describe the plan to complete the implementation.

by-components.description: AGC has developed, disseminated, and annually reviews a formal, documented system and information integrity policy and procedures to ensure consistent implementation across the organization. This policy establishes a comprehensive framework for ensuring the integrity, security, and reliability of AGC's information systems and data, protecting against unauthorized access, modification, and destruction.

values: Chief Information Security Officer, Program Manager, IT Security Team

by-components.description: AGC has developed and documented a comprehensive system and information integrity policy that addresses purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, management commitment, coordination among organizational entities, and compliance with relevant laws and regulations.

The system and information integrity policy is documented and maintained as part of AGC's overall information security policy framework. It provides guidance on implementing and maintaining system and information integrity controls across all organizational systems and networks.

AGC has established procedures to facilitate the implementation of the system and information integrity policy and associated controls. These procedures detail the steps for identifying, reporting, and correcting information system flaws, protecting against malicious code, and monitoring system security alerts and advisories.

AGC reviews and updates the system and information integrity policy at least every 3 years to ensure it remains relevant and aligned with organizational goals, industry best practices, and regulatory requirements.

AGC reviews and updates the system and information integrity procedures at least annually to ensure they effectively support the implementation of the policy and address any changes in the operational environment or regulatory landscape.

AGC implements spam protection mechanisms at information system entry and exit points to detect and take action on unsolicited messages. The organization employs DMARC, SPF, and DKIM technologies to enhance email security and reduce the risk of phishing and spam attacks.

values: Chief Information Security Officer, IT Security Team

props.remarks: Describe the plan to complete the implementation.

resources.title: Resolution Resource
resources.remarks: This \"resolution resource\" is used by FedRAMP as a local, authoritative indicator of what version SSP (rev 4 or rev 5) this OSCAL document is for.

FedRAMP is formulating guidelines for handling digital/electronic signatures in OSCAL, and welcome feedback on solutions.

For now, FedRAMP recommends one of the following:

* Render the OSCAL SSP content as a PDF that is digitally signed and attached.
* Render the OSCAL SSP content as a printed page that is physically signed, scanned, and attached.


If your organization prefers another approach, please seek prior approval from the FedRAMP PMO.
